title: Subacute Combined Degeneration
icd10: G32.0 (Subacute combined degeneration of spinal cord in diseases classified elsewhere)
scope: ** Evaluation and management of subacute combined degeneration (SCD) of the spinal cord, focusing on myelopathy from posterior column and lateral corticospinal tract demyelination. Covers B12 deficiency as the primary etiology, with additional coverage of copper deficiency and nitrous oxide toxicity as alternative/contributory causes. Includes diagnostic workup with emphasis on MRI findings, B12 replacement protocols, spasticity management, rehabilitation, and long-term monitoring. Complements the existing B12 Deficiency Neuropathy plan (which focuses on peripheral nerve involvement). Excludes pure peripheral neuropathy without myelopathy and pure hematologic B12 deficiency without neurological involvement.

Essential/Core Labs.rationale: Confirm B12 deficiency; <200 pg/mL diagnostic; 200-400 pg/mL borderline; SCD can occur with borderline levels
Most sensitive marker of tissue B12 deficiency; elevated even when serum B12 borderline; essential for diagnosis when B12 is 200-400 pg/mL
Elevated in both B12 and folate deficiency; supports metabolic B12 deficiency when MMA elevated
Macrocytic anemia (MCV >100) supports B12 deficiency; however 25-30% of SCD patients have normal MCV; hypersegmented neutrophils; pancytopenia possible
Macro-ovalocytes, hypersegmented neutrophils (>=5 lobes); megaloblastic changes; absence does not exclude SCD
Renal dysfunction affects MMA interpretation; LDH elevated in megaloblastic anemia; electrolytes for potassium monitoring during replacement
Rule out concurrent folate deficiency; folate replacement alone may worsen SCD neurological damage by correcting anemia while masking B12 deficiency
Markedly elevated in megaloblastic anemia due to intramedullary hemolysis and ineffective erythropoiesis
Low in megaloblastic anemia; reticulocyte crisis at day 5-7 of treatment confirms response
Copper deficiency produces myelopathy identical to B12 SCD; must be excluded in all cases; may co-occur with B12 deficiency post-bariatric surgery
Excess zinc supplementation causes copper depletion; common cause of copper-deficient myelopathy

Extended Workup (Etiology).rationale: Highly specific (>95%) for pernicious anemia; sensitivity ~50-70%; positive result confirms autoimmune etiology
Sensitive (~80-90%) but less specific for pernicious anemia; positive in other autoimmune conditions
Elevated in pernicious anemia due to achlorhydria; helps confirm autoimmune atrophic gastritis
Low in copper deficiency; aids in confirming copper-deficient myelopathy when copper level low
Autoimmune thyroid disease co-occurs with pernicious anemia (autoimmune polyglandular syndrome)
Celiac disease screening; celiac causes malabsorption of B12 and copper at terminal ileum
IgA deficiency causes false-negative celiac serologies; must order with tTG-IgA
Co-existing iron deficiency may mask macrocytosis; combined deficiency common in pernicious anemia
Biologically active B12 fraction; may detect early deficiency before total B12 falls
Vitamin E deficiency causes spinocerebellar ataxia and posterior column dysfunction mimicking SCD
HIV-associated vacuolar myelopathy mimics SCD; may coexist with B12 deficiency

Extended Workup (Etiology).item: Nitrous oxide exposure history (urine or serum)
Extended Workup (Etiology).rationale: N2O irreversibly oxidizes B12; recreational use or occupational exposure causes acute SCD; B12 may be normal with elevated MMA

Rare/Specialized (Refractory or Atypical.rationale: Urine MMA may be more reliable in renal insufficiency than serum MMA
Inborn errors of cobalamin metabolism; young patients with B12-resistant myelopathy and no dietary/malabsorptive cause
Rare genetic deficiency causing functional B12 deficiency with normal serum B12; consider in pediatric SCD
Paraneoplastic myelopathy mimics SCD; subacute onset, weight loss, smoking history
Monoclonal gammopathy can cause myelopathy mimicking SCD
Longitudinally extensive transverse myelitis (NMOSD, MOGAD) in differential of long-segment spinal cord T2 lesions

Rare/Specialized (Refractory or Atypical.item: CSF oligoclonal bands and IgG index
Rare/Specialized (Refractory or Atypical.rationale: Multiple sclerosis in differential when MRI shows spinal cord demyelination
Neurosyphilis (tabes dorsalis) causes posterior column dysfunction; mimics SCD

Essential/First-line.item: MRI cervical spine with and without contrast
Essential/First-line.timing: URGENT if myelopathy symptoms (gait ataxia, spasticity, Lhermitte sign, bladder symptoms)
Essential/First-line.target: Bilateral symmetric T2 hyperintensity in posterior columns ("inverted V sign" on axial images); may extend into lateral columns; typically cervical and upper thoracic; no enhancement in classic SCD; enhancement suggests active demyelination or alternative diagnosis
Essential/First-line.contraindications: GFR <30 for gadolinium; pacemaker; metal implants

Essential/First-line.item: MRI thoracic spine with and without contrast
Essential/First-line.timing: URGENT if cervical MRI does not fully explain symptoms; SCD often involves both cervical and thoracic segments
Essential/First-line.target: Bilateral symmetric posterior column T2 hyperintensity; similar pattern to cervical spine; may be the primary or only segment involved
Essential/First-line.contraindications: GFR <30 for gadolinium; pacemaker; metal implants

Essential/First-line.timing: Baseline evaluation; optimal 3-4 weeks after symptom onset
Essential/First-line.target: Axonal sensorimotor polyneuropathy; reduced sensory amplitudes (especially sural nerve); superimposed peripheral neuropathy common in SCD; helps quantify peripheral nerve involvement

Extended.item: MRI brain with and without contrast
Extended.timing: If cognitive impairment, encephalopathy, or optic neuropathy; to exclude MS or other central demyelination
Extended.target: White matter changes; exclude MS plaques (periventricular, corpus callosum); cerebral atrophy (chronic B12 deficiency)

Extended.timing: If clinical myelopathy suspected but MRI equivocal or normal; quantifies posterior column function
Extended.target: Prolonged central conduction time confirming dorsal column dysfunction; may be abnormal before MRI shows changes

Extended.timing: If visual symptoms or optic neuropathy suspected; B12 deficiency can cause optic neuropathy
If pernicious anemia confirmed; screen for atrophic gastritis and gastric carcinoid (3-fold increased risk)
Extended.target: Atrophic gastritis; intestinal metaplasia; rule out gastric carcinoid/adenocarcinoma

Extended.timing: If bladder dysfunction present (urinary urgency, retention, incontinence from lateral column involvement)
Extended.target: Neurogenic bladder pattern (detrusor overactivity or underactivity)

Rare/Specialized.timing: If small bowel malabsorption suspected (celiac, Crohn, bacterial overgrowth)
If small intestinal bacterial overgrowth (SIBO) suspected as cause of B12 malabsorption
Research setting; if conventional MRI equivocal; may show reduced NAA/Cr ratio in affected segments

Acute/Emergent - B12 Replacement and Eti.indication: Confirmed or suspected B12 deficiency with myelopathy; initiate immediately while awaiting confirmatory labs; do not delay treatment for SCD

doseOptions.orderSentence: Cyanocobalamin IM 1000 mcg daily x 7 days IM

dosing.instructions: 1000 mcg IM daily x 7 days, then 1000 mcg IM weekly x 4 weeks, then 1000 mcg IM monthly indefinitely; neurological SCD requires aggressive initial dosing
dosing.orderSentence: Cyanocobalamin IM 1000 mcg daily x 7 days IM

Acute/Emergent - B12 Replacement and Eti.contraindications: Cobalt or cobalamin hypersensitivity (rare); Leber hereditary optic neuropathy (relative)
Acute/Emergent - B12 Replacement and Eti.monitoring: Reticulocyte count at day 5-7 (reticulocyte crisis confirms response); B12 and MMA at 1-2 months; CBC at 1-2 months; potassium during first 48 hours (hypokalemia from erythropoiesis); neurological exam serial

Acute/Emergent - B12 Replacement and Eti.indication: Alternative to cyanocobalamin; longer-acting; preferred when N2O toxicity is the cause (directly replaces oxidized B12); also used for cyanide poisoning

doseOptions.orderSentence: Hydroxocobalamin IM 1000 mcg daily x 7 days IM

dosing.instructions: 1000 mcg IM daily x 7 days, then 1000 mcg IM every other day x 2 weeks, then 1000 mcg IM monthly indefinitely; preferred for N2O-induced SCD
dosing.orderSentence: Hydroxocobalamin IM 1000 mcg daily x 7 days IM

Acute/Emergent - B12 Replacement and Eti.contraindications: Cobalt or cobalamin hypersensitivity (rare); Leber hereditary optic neuropathy (relative)
Acute/Emergent - B12 Replacement and Eti.monitoring: Reticulocyte count at day 5-7; B12 and MMA at 1-2 months; CBC at 1-2 months; potassium during first 48 hours (hypokalemia from erythropoiesis); chromaturia (red urine) expected

Acute/Emergent - B12 Replacement and Eti.indication: If IM injection contraindicated (anticoagulation, severe thrombocytopenia) or patient preference; slightly lower bioavailability than IM

doseOptions.orderSentence: Cyanocobalamin SC 1000 mcg daily x 7 days SC

dosing.instructions: 1000 mcg SC daily x 7 days, then 1000 mcg SC weekly x 4 weeks, then 1000 mcg SC monthly indefinitely
dosing.orderSentence: Cyanocobalamin SC 1000 mcg daily x 7 days SC

Acute/Emergent - B12 Replacement and Eti.contraindications: Cobalt or cobalamin hypersensitivity (rare); Leber hereditary optic neuropathy (relative)
Acute/Emergent - B12 Replacement and Eti.monitoring: Reticulocyte count at day 5-7; B12 and MMA at 1-2 months; CBC at 1-2 months; potassium during first 48 hours (hypokalemia from erythropoiesis)

Acute/Emergent - B12 Replacement and Eti.indication: Copper deficiency myelopathy confirmed (low serum copper and ceruloplasmin); oral replacement for mild-moderate deficiency

doseOptions.orderSentence: Copper gluconate (for copper-deficient SCD) 2 mg TID PO

dosing.instructions: 2 mg elemental copper PO TID for 1 week, then 2 mg PO daily for maintenance; recheck copper at 4-8 weeks
dosing.orderSentence: Copper gluconate (for copper-deficient SCD) 2 mg TID PO

Acute/Emergent - B12 Replacement and Eti.monitoring: Serum copper and ceruloplasmin at 4-8 weeks and every 3-6 months; zinc level (discontinue excess zinc); CBC for neutropenia recovery

Acute/Emergent - B12 Replacement and Eti.item: Copper chloride IV (for severe copper deficiency)
Acute/Emergent - B12 Replacement and Eti.indication: Severe symptomatic copper deficiency with progressive myelopathy or unable to absorb oral copper

doseOptions.orderSentence: Copper chloride IV (for severe copper deficiency) 2 mg daily x 5 days IV

dosing.instructions: 2 mg elemental copper IV daily for 5 days, then transition to oral copper 2 mg PO daily
dosing.orderSentence: Copper chloride IV (for severe copper deficiency) 2 mg daily x 5 days IV

Acute/Emergent - B12 Replacement and Eti.monitoring: Serum copper at 1 week post-IV; LFTs; cardiac monitoring during infusion

Acute/Emergent - B12 Replacement and Eti.indication: Prevent hypokalemia during B12 replacement; rapid erythropoiesis consumes potassium; risk of cardiac arrhythmia

doseOptions.orderSentence: Potassium supplementation 20 mEq daily PRN PO

dosing.instructions: 20-40 mEq PO daily; monitor potassium q12-24h during first 48 hours of B12 replacement; supplement if K <3.5 mEq/L; IV KCl 10-20 mEq/hr for severe hypokalemia
dosing.orderSentence: Potassium supplementation 20 mEq daily PRN PO

Acute/Emergent - B12 Replacement and Eti.contraindications: Hyperkalemia; renal failure (use cautiously); K >5.0 mEq/L
Acute/Emergent - B12 Replacement and Eti.monitoring: Potassium levels q12-24h during initial treatment; ECG if K <3.0 mEq/L

Acute/Emergent - B12 Replacement and Eti.indication: Correct concurrent folate deficiency; MUST administer with B12 to avoid masking deficiency; folate alone worsens SCD

dosing.instructions: 1 mg PO daily; NEVER give folate without concurrent B12 in suspected B12 deficiency (corrects anemia while neurological damage progresses silently)

Acute/Emergent - B12 Replacement and Eti.monitoring: Ensure B12 is being co-administered; reticulocyte count

Acute/Emergent - B12 Replacement and Eti.item: Methylprednisolone IV (for N2O-induced SCD with severe acute myelopathy)
Acute/Emergent - B12 Replacement and Eti.indication: Acute severe N2O-induced myelopathy with rapidly progressive weakness; reduces inflammatory demyelination; used in select cases with significant cord edema

doseOptions.orderSentence: Methylprednisolone IV (for N2O-induced SCD with severe acute myelopathy) 1000 mg daily x 3-5 days IV

dosing.instructions: 1000 mg IV daily for 3-5 days; concurrent with B12 replacement; consider if MRI shows cord edema or enhancement; evidence limited to case series
dosing.orderSentence: Methylprednisolone IV (for N2O-induced SCD with severe acute myelopathy) 1000 mg daily x 3-5 days IV

Acute/Emergent - B12 Replacement and Eti.contraindications: Active infection; uncontrolled diabetes; GI bleeding; psychosis
Acute/Emergent - B12 Replacement and Eti.monitoring: Blood glucose q6h; BP monitoring; GI prophylaxis with PPI; infection screening; psychiatric monitoring

Symptomatic Treatments.indication: Spasticity from lateral corticospinal tract involvement; lower extremity stiffness and spasms

dosing.instructions: Start 5 mg TID; titrate by 5 mg/dose every 3 days; target 30-80 mg/day divided TID; max 80 mg/day; taper to discontinue (do not stop abruptly - risk of withdrawal seizures)

Symptomatic Treatments.contraindications: Renal impairment (dose reduce); epilepsy (lowers seizure threshold)
Symptomatic Treatments.monitoring: Sedation, weakness, dizziness; taper gradually to discontinue; monitor for urinary retention

Symptomatic Treatments.indication: Spasticity (alternative to baclofen); especially if baclofen causes excessive weakness

dosing.instructions: Start 2 mg qHS; titrate by 2 mg every 3-4 days; max 36 mg/day divided TID; significant sedation limits daytime use

Symptomatic Treatments.contraindications: Hepatic impairment; concurrent CYP1A2 inhibitors (fluvoxamine, ciprofloxacin - contraindicated)
Symptomatic Treatments.monitoring: LFTs at baseline, 1, 3, and 6 months; sedation, dry mouth, hypotension; hepatotoxicity rare but serious

Symptomatic Treatments.indication: Neuropathic pain (burning, tingling, shooting pain); first-line for SCD-associated neuropathic pain

dosing.instructions: Start 300 mg qHS; titrate by 300 mg every 1-3 days to TID dosing; target 900-1800 mg/day divided TID; max 3600 mg/day; adjust for renal function (CrCl 30-59: max 1400 mg/day; CrCl 15-29: max 700 mg/day; CrCl <15: max 300 mg/day)

Symptomatic Treatments.contraindications: Severe renal impairment (dose adjust required); respiratory depression with concurrent opioids
Symptomatic Treatments.monitoring: Sedation, dizziness, peripheral edema; taper to discontinue (do not stop abruptly)

Symptomatic Treatments.indication: Neuropathic pain (first-line alternative to gabapentin); useful when gabapentin ineffective or poorly tolerated

dosing.instructions: Start 75 mg BID; may increase to 150 mg BID after 1 week; max 300 mg BID (600 mg/day); adjust for renal function (CrCl <60: reduce dose); Schedule V controlled substance

Symptomatic Treatments.contraindications: Severe renal impairment (dose adjust required); history of substance abuse (relative)
Symptomatic Treatments.monitoring: Sedation, weight gain, peripheral edema; dizziness; taper to discontinue

Symptomatic Treatments.indication: Neuropathic pain (first-line); particularly effective for painful neuropathy with comorbid depression or anxiety

dosing.instructions: Start 30 mg daily x 1 week; increase to 60 mg daily; max 120 mg/day

Symptomatic Treatments.contraindications: Hepatic impairment; CrCl <30; concurrent MAOIs; uncontrolled narrow-angle glaucoma
Symptomatic Treatments.monitoring: Nausea (usually transient); BP monitoring; discontinuation syndrome (taper over 2+ weeks)

Symptomatic Treatments.indication: Neuropathic pain (second-line); useful for concurrent insomnia and neuropathic pain

dosing.instructions: Start 10-25 mg qHS; increase by 10-25 mg weekly; max 150 mg qHS

Symptomatic Treatments.contraindications: Cardiac conduction abnormality; recent MI; urinary retention; narrow-angle glaucoma; elderly (anticholinergic burden)
Symptomatic Treatments.monitoring: ECG if dose >100 mg/day; anticholinergic effects; sedation; weight gain

Symptomatic Treatments.indication: Neurogenic bladder with detrusor overactivity (urgency, frequency, urge incontinence) from lateral column involvement

dosing.instructions: Start 5 mg BID; may increase to 5 mg TID; max 5 mg QID (20 mg/day); extended-release formulation 5-30 mg daily preferred for fewer side effects

Symptomatic Treatments.contraindications: Uncontrolled narrow-angle glaucoma; urinary retention; GI obstruction; myasthenia gravis
Symptomatic Treatments.monitoring: Anticholinergic effects (dry mouth, constipation, cognitive impairment in elderly); post-void residual if retention suspected

Symptomatic Treatments.indication: Neurogenic bladder with urinary retention from sacral cord involvement

dosing.instructions: 0.4 mg PO daily; may increase to 0.8 mg daily if inadequate response; take 30 minutes after same meal daily

Symptomatic Treatments.contraindications: Severe hepatic impairment; concurrent strong CYP3A4 inhibitors
Symptomatic Treatments.monitoring: Orthostatic hypotension (especially first dose); dizziness; retrograde ejaculation

Symptomatic Treatments.indication: Constipation from autonomic dysfunction or immobility; common in SCD patients

dosing.instructions: 17 g (1 capful) dissolved in 8 oz liquid daily; adjust frequency for bowel regularity

Symptomatic Treatments.contraindications: Bowel obstruction; known or suspected GI perforation
Symptomatic Treatments.monitoring: Diarrhea if excessive dosing; electrolytes if prolonged use

Symptomatic Treatments.indication: Depression comorbid with chronic myelopathy; reactive depression from functional decline and disability

dosing.instructions: Start 50 mg daily; increase by 25-50 mg every 1-2 weeks; max 200 mg/day

Symptomatic Treatments.monitoring: Suicidality monitoring (first 4 weeks); serotonin syndrome if combined with other serotonergic agents; sexual dysfunction

Second-line/Refractory.indication: Neuropathic pain refractory to gabapentinoids; particularly if comorbid depression

dosing.instructions: Start 37.5 mg daily; increase by 75 mg every 4-7 days; target 150 mg daily; max 225 mg/day

Second-line/Refractory.monitoring: BP monitoring (dose-dependent hypertension); serotonin syndrome; discontinuation syndrome (taper over 2+ weeks)

Second-line/Refractory.indication: Neuropathic pain (second-line TCA); fewer anticholinergic effects than amitriptyline

dosing.instructions: Start 10-25 mg qHS; increase by 10-25 mg weekly; max 150 mg qHS

Second-line/Refractory.contraindications: Cardiac conduction abnormality; recent MI; urinary retention; narrow-angle glaucoma; elderly
Second-line/Refractory.monitoring: ECG if dose >100 mg/day; anticholinergic effects (fewer than amitriptyline); sedation

Second-line/Refractory.indication: Severe spasticity refractory to baclofen and tizanidine; acts peripherally on skeletal muscle

dosing.instructions: Start 25 mg daily; increase by 25 mg every 4-7 days to TID; target 75-100 mg TID; max 400 mg/day

Second-line/Refractory.contraindications: Active hepatic disease; concurrent hepatotoxic medications
Second-line/Refractory.monitoring: LFTs at baseline, then monthly for 6 months; hepatotoxicity risk (idiosyncratic, potentially fatal); weakness (reduces muscle contractility)

Second-line/Refractory.item: High-dose oral B12 (if parenteral refused or contraindicated)
Second-line/Refractory.indication: B12 replacement when IM/SC injections refused or contraindicated; ~1% absorbed passively independent of intrinsic factor

doseOptions.orderSentence: High-dose oral B12 (if parenteral refused or contraindicated) 2000 mcg daily PO

dosing.instructions: 2000 mcg PO daily; higher dose recommended for myelopathy than for neuropathy alone; monitor closely; switch to parenteral if MMA does not normalize within 2-3 months
dosing.orderSentence: High-dose oral B12 (if parenteral refused or contraindicated) 2000 mcg daily PO

Second-line/Refractory.monitoring: B12 and MMA levels at 2-3 months to confirm adequate absorption; if MMA remains elevated, switch to parenteral; neurological examination

Second-line/Refractory.indication: Alternative oral B12 formulation; may have improved bioavailability; patient preference for non-injection route

dosing.instructions: 5000 mcg sublingual daily; dissolve under tongue; efficacy data limited compared to IM; not preferred as first-line for myelopathy

Second-line/Refractory.monitoring: B12 and MMA levels at 2-3 months; switch to parenteral if inadequate response or MMA remains elevated

Second-line/Refractory.indication: Moderate neuropathic pain refractory to first-line agents

dosing.instructions: Start 50 mg q6h PRN; may increase to 100 mg q6h; max 400 mg/day; ER formulation 100-300 mg daily

Second-line/Refractory.contraindications: Seizure disorder; concurrent MAOIs; concurrent SSRIs/SNRIs (serotonin syndrome risk)
Second-line/Refractory.monitoring: Seizure risk; serotonin syndrome; dependence (Schedule IV); constipation

Second-line/Refractory.indication: Focal spasticity refractory to oral medications; targeted treatment for specific muscle groups (gastrocnemius, hamstrings, hip adductors)

doseOptions.orderSentence: Botulinum toxin type A (onabotulinumtoxinA) Per muscle group IM

dosing.instructions: Dose varies by muscle: gastrocnemius 75-200 units per leg; hamstrings 50-200 units; hip adductors 75-200 units; onset 3-7 days; peak 2-6 weeks; repeat every 12 weeks
dosing.orderSentence: Botulinum toxin type A (onabotulinumtoxinA) Per muscle group IM

Second-line/Refractory.contraindications: Infection at injection site; myasthenia gravis; aminoglycoside use (potentiates blockade)
Second-line/Refractory.monitoring: Weakness beyond target muscles; dysphagia (if cervical muscles treated); antibody formation with repeated use

Referrals & Consults.item: Neurology consultation for confirmation of SCD diagnosis, differentiation from compressive myelopathy or MS, and monitoring of neurological recovery
Physical therapy for gait training, balance exercises, proprioceptive rehabilitation, and fall prevention given posterior column dysfunction and sensory ataxia
Occupational therapy for upper extremity fine motor rehabilitation and adaptive equipment for impaired hand dexterity from posterior column involvement
Hematology referral for evaluation of persistent macrocytic anemia, pancytopenia, or unexplained cytopenias not responding to B12 replacement
Gastroenterology referral for EGD and evaluation of pernicious anemia, atrophic gastritis, malabsorption etiology, or gastric carcinoid surveillance
Urology referral for evaluation and management of neurogenic bladder (urgency, retention, incontinence) from lateral column involvement
Rehabilitation medicine (physiatry) consultation for comprehensive inpatient rehabilitation program if significant functional impairment from myelopathy
Endocrinology referral for evaluation of concurrent autoimmune thyroid disease in patients with confirmed pernicious anemia (autoimmune polyglandular syndrome)
Nutrition/Dietitian referral for dietary counseling regarding B12-rich and copper-rich foods, especially for vegans, vegetarians, and post-bariatric patients
Pain management referral for refractory neuropathic pain and spasticity not responding to first- and second-line pharmacotherapy after adequate B12 normalization
Neuropsychological testing for cognitive assessment if persistent cognitive impairment despite B12 normalization, to differentiate from comorbid dementia
Social work consult for assistance with self-injection training, disability resources, home care coordination, and durable medical equipment procurement
Addiction medicine or psychiatry referral if nitrous oxide abuse is the underlying cause of SCD for substance use disorder treatment and relapse prevention

Patient Instructions.item: Return immediately if worsening leg weakness, new difficulty walking, or new bladder/bowel dysfunction develops (may indicate progressive myelopathy requiring urgent evaluation and treatment adjustment)
B12 injections are lifelong if pernicious anemia is the cause; stopping injections will cause myelopathy to recur and worsen, potentially with irreversible damage

Neurological recovery from SCD is slow and may take 6-18 months; posterior column symptoms (balance, proprioception) may improve incompletely, especially if treatment was delayed more than 6 months from symptom onset
Do not take folate supplements without B12 as folate alone may correct anemia while allowing neurological damage from SCD to continue progressing silently

Inform all healthcare providers and anesthesia teams of B12 deficiency before any surgical procedure; nitrous oxide (N2O) used in anesthesia irreversibly oxidizes B12 and can precipitate acute catastrophic neurological deterioration
If self-administering B12 injections, use proper IM technique and rotate injection sites (outer thigh or deltoid); attend injection training with nursing before discharge
Use assistive devices (walker, cane) as recommended by physical therapy for safety during ambulation given impaired proprioception and balance
Inspect feet daily for cuts, blisters, or wounds using a mirror for soles; impaired sensation from posterior column dysfunction increases injury risk
Report new numbness, tingling, increasing stiffness, or changes in bladder function to your neurologist as this may indicate inadequate treatment or disease progression
Do not stop baclofen or other antispasticity medications abruptly as this may cause withdrawal symptoms including seizures and rebound spasticity
If nitrous oxide (whippets, laughing gas) was the cause, complete cessation is mandatory as any re-exposure will cause further irreversible spinal cord damage

Lifestyle & Prevention.item: Complete alcohol cessation as alcohol independently causes neuropathy, worsens B12 malabsorption, and impairs neurological recovery
Complete cessation of nitrous oxide use (recreational or occupational) as any exposure causes further irreversible oxidation of B12 and spinal cord damage
Smoking cessation to improve vascular health, support neural recovery, and reduce risk of gastric malignancy in pernicious anemia patients
Fall prevention: remove throw rugs, ensure adequate lighting, install grab bars in bathroom, use assistive devices (walker, cane) for sensory ataxia and impaired proprioception
Dietary sources of B12: meat, fish, eggs, dairy, fortified cereals; copper-rich foods: shellfish, nuts, seeds, organ meats, dark chocolate; supplement if dietary intake insufficient
If vegan or vegetarian, lifelong B12 supplementation is required as plant-based diets contain no natural B12 sources

Regular supervised exercise as tolerated (swimming, stationary bike, seated exercises) to maintain strength and cardiovascular health; avoid exercises requiring intact proprioception without supervision or assistive devices
Avoid excessive zinc supplementation (>40 mg/day) as zinc competes with copper absorption and can cause copper-deficient myelopathy
Avoid excessive vitamin B6 supplementation (>100 mg/day) which independently causes peripheral neuropathy and may worsen symptoms
Annual screening for gastric carcinoid/adenocarcinoma if pernicious anemia confirmed (3-fold increased risk of gastric cancer)
Review medications for B12-lowering agents: proton pump inhibitors, H2 blockers, metformin, colchicine; dose adjustment or monitoring may be needed
Metformin users: annual B12 and MMA screening as metformin reduces B12 absorption by 10-30% and may precipitate or worsen SCD
Home safety evaluation by occupational therapy to identify and eliminate fall hazards given sensory ataxia and proprioceptive loss
Test bath water temperature with elbow before entering as impaired sensation from posterior column dysfunction increases burn risk

differential.features: Clinically identical to B12-related SCD; often post-bariatric surgery, zinc excess, or malabsorption; may co-occur with B12 deficiency; neutropenia and anemia without macrocytosis more common
differential.tests: Serum copper, ceruloplasmin; zinc level; B12 and MMA may be normal; neutropenia with normal MCV suggests copper over B12

differential.features: Demyelinating lesions; relapsing-remitting course; dissemination in time and space; younger females; optic neuritis common; asymmetric deficits
differential.tests: MRI brain shows periventricular, juxtacortical, and infratentorial lesions; CSF oligoclonal bands; normal B12 and MMA; contrast-enhancing lesions common

differential.features: Compressive myelopathy; neck pain; progressive upper motor neuron signs; age-related degenerative disease; may coexist with SCD
differential.tests: MRI cervical spine shows structural cord compression from disc/osteophyte; B12 and MMA normal; focal rather than diffuse posterior column signal

differential.features: Similar posterior column involvement; occurs with advanced AIDS (CD4 <200); may coexist with B12 deficiency; progressive spastic paraparesis
differential.tests: HIV testing; CD4 count; may coexist with B12 deficiency; CSF HIV viral load

differential.features: Posterior column dysfunction; lightning pains; Argyll Robertson pupils; progressive sensory ataxia; decades after primary infection
differential.tests: RPR/VDRL; FTA-ABS; CSF VDRL; lymphocytic pleocytosis in CSF

differential.features: Longitudinally extensive transverse myelitis (>3 segments); severe attacks; optic neuritis; may involve posterior columns
differential.tests: Aquaporin-4 (NMO-IgG) antibodies; MRI shows longitudinally extensive lesion; contrast enhancement; CSF pleocytosis

differential.features: Acute/subacute SCD-like syndrome; recreational N2O use (whippets); occupational exposure; B12 may be normal but MMA elevated; rapid onset days to weeks
differential.tests: History of N2O exposure; B12 may be normal or low; MMA elevated; rapid onset distinguishes from insidious B12 deficiency

differential.features: Progressive sensory ataxia; cardiomyopathy; onset in youth (<25); autosomal recessive; scoliosis; pes cavus
differential.tests: Genetic testing (GAA trinucleotide repeat in FXN gene); normal B12; ECG/echo for cardiomyopathy

differential.features: Spinocerebellar ataxia; proprioceptive loss; may mimic posterior column disease; fat malabsorption states
differential.tests: Serum vitamin E level; fat-soluble vitamin panel; associated with fat malabsorption syndromes

differential.features: Slowly progressive spastic paraparesis; family history; no sensory loss typically; pure vs complicated forms
differential.tests: Genetic testing; no posterior column T2 signal; B12 and copper normal; family history

differential.features: Subacute progressive myelopathy; weight loss; smoking history; may involve posterior or lateral columns
differential.tests: Paraneoplastic antibodies (anti-Hu, CV2, amphiphysin); CT chest/abdomen/pelvis; PET scan

differential.features: Progressive spastic paraparesis with adrenal insufficiency; onset in young men; family history of ALD
differential.tests: Very long chain fatty acids (VLCFA) elevated; adrenal function tests; genetic testing (ABCD1 gene)

differential.features: Pure upper motor neuron disease; spasticity without sensory findings; no posterior column involvement
differential.tests: Normal B12 and MMA; no sensory loss; no posterior column signal on MRI; EMG without denervation

monitoring.frequency: 1-2 months after starting treatment, then every 6-12 months
monitoring.action: If persistently low on oral, switch to parenteral; increase dose; assess compliance

monitoring.frequency: 2-3 months after starting treatment, then annually
monitoring.action: If elevated despite supplementation, evaluate compliance and absorption; switch to parenteral if on oral; reassess diagnosis
If elevated, check folate; assess compliance; consider alternative etiology

monitoring.frequency: Day 5-7 (reticulocyte crisis); 1-2 months; then every 6-12 months
monitoring.action: If no reticulocyte response, reconsider diagnosis; check folate, iron, copper

monitoring.frequency: Q12-24h during first 48 hours of B12 replacement
monitoring.action: Supplement potassium; severe hypokalemia can cause cardiac arrhythmia; IV replacement for K <3.0 mEq/L

monitoring.frequency: 4-8 weeks after starting copper supplementation, then every 3-6 months
monitoring.action: Increase copper dose; investigate ongoing losses; reassess zinc intake

monitoring.item: Neurological examination (motor, sensory, proprioception, Romberg, gait, reflexes, Babinski, tone)
monitoring.frequency: Each visit; formal assessment at 3, 6, 12 months
monitoring.action: If worsening, re-evaluate diagnosis; check B12/MMA/copper; consider additional causes; reassess compliance

monitoring.frequency: 6-12 months after treatment initiation; then PRN for clinical change
monitoring.action: If worsening or new lesions despite treatment, reconsider diagnosis (MS, NMOSD); check compliance; evaluate for concurrent copper deficiency

monitoring.frequency: Each visit; standardized tools (Timed Up and Go, Berg Balance Scale)
monitoring.action: PT referral or intensification; assistive devices; home safety evaluation
Adjust antispasticity medications; consider botulinum toxin; physiatry referral

monitoring.frequency: Each visit if bladder symptoms present
monitoring.action: Urology referral; adjust bladder medications; urodynamic studies if worsening
Titrate pain medications; consider combination therapy or referral to pain management

monitoring.frequency: 6-12 months after treatment; then PRN for symptom change
monitoring.action: If progressive despite treatment, reconsider diagnosis or look for additional etiology
Iron supplementation if deficient (combined deficiency common in pernicious anemia)
Gastroenterology referral for management of premalignant lesions
Insulin sliding scale or infusion; endocrinology consult if persistent hyperglycemia

disposition.criteria: Stable neurological examination; able to ambulate safely (with assistive device if needed); reliable follow-up arranged with neurology; B12 injection initiated and plan established; caregiver available for injection administration or self-injection training completed; no severe hypokalemia or electrolyte abnormality; bladder function adequate; fall risk acceptably managed

Acute or subacute myelopathy with gait impairment (unable to ambulate safely); progressive neurological deficits requiring serial examinations; severe spasticity or spasms requiring medication titration; need for frequent electrolyte monitoring during initial B12 replacement; new bladder/bowel dysfunction requiring evaluation; falls requiring inpatient rehabilitation assessment; severe pancytopenia requiring monitoring

Severe symptomatic anemia with hemodynamic instability requiring transfusion; high-output cardiac failure from severe anemia; severe hypokalemia with cardiac monitoring need during B12 replacement; respiratory compromise from severe weakness; rapidly progressive myelopathy from N2O toxicity requiring close neurological monitoring; steroid-related complications (severe hyperglycemia, psychosis)

Neurology consultation not available for myelopathy evaluation; MRI not available for urgent spinal cord imaging; EMG/NCS not available for diagnostic workup; inpatient rehabilitation facility needed but not available locally; neurosurgery evaluation needed to exclude compressive myelopathy
